awd_titl_txt: Developing anisotropic media for transformation optics by using dielectric photonic crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Novel media for transformation optics using dielectric photonic crystals

Non-Technical Description: 
Transformation optics (TO) is based on coordinate transformations, which require proper spatial dispersions of the media parameters. Such media force electromagnetic (EM) waves, moving in the original coordinate system, to behave as if they propagate in a transformed coordinate system. Thus TO introduces a new powerful technique for designing advanced EM devices with superior functionalities. Coordinate transformations can be derived for compressing, expanding, bending, or twisting space, enabling designs of invisibility cloaks, field concentrators, perfect lenses, beam shifters, etc., that may bring advances to various areas of human life. Realization of these devices depends on the possibility of creating media with prescribed EM properties, in particular, directional refractive indices to provide wave propagation with superluminal phase velocities and high refractive indices in the normal direction to cause wave movement along curvilinear paths.  Originally, artificial metamaterials (MMs) composed of tiny metallic resonators were chosen for building transformation media. However, a number of serious challenges were encountered, such as extremely narrow frequency band of operation and the high losses in metal elements. The proposed approach is to use dielectric photonic crystals to overcome these major limitations of MM media. This project will allow graduate and undergraduate students, especially women in engineering, to participate in theoretical and experimental EM research. Outreach activities include lectures and hands-on projects in several youth programs to K-12 students.

Technical Description: 
This project will develop a platform for engineering photonic crystal (PhC)-based media that are free from the major limitations of metamaterial media. The project aims to control wave propagation in media along orthogonal crystallographic directions and relies upon self-collimation phenomena at formulating TO-based prescriptions for refractive indices. For realizing directional dispersions of both superluminal and ordinary indices along desired axes of crystals, proper variations of their lattice parameters will be used. Accurate control of index values will be provided by building the media from crystal fragments with optimized dimensions. Microwave experiments using a parallel-plate waveguide chamber will be performed to record wave propagation and to verify computational results.   Technologies developed earlier for fabricating low-loss PhCs will help to implement the practical devices. This interdisciplinary research will integrate electromagnetics, physics, optics, and materials science concepts; employ full-wave computational modeling and design; engineer complex materials architectures; and master characterization techniques for complex structures. The project will open up perspectives for TO by developing new approaches for media engineering and by solving fundamental problems, including integration of self-collimation. This research will integrate electromagnetics, physics, optics, and materials science concepts and will advance the potential of PhCs.

por.por_cntn:
The science of transformation optics (TO) provides a powerful tool for creating electromagnetic devices with unprecedented functionalities, which could bring advances into various areas of human life. TO employs coordinate transformations to bend wave paths and control wave flows. To make waves follow new trajectories, coordinate transformations should be accompanied by respective transformations of material properties of the medium. Deriving coordinate transformations for compressing, expanding, bending, or twisting space, enables designs of invisibility cloaks, field concentrators, perfect lenses, beam shifters, etc. However, realization of these devices demands transformation media with prescribed material parameters, which, as a rule, are not accessible in natural materials. While the first TO media were built from metamaterials (MMs), i.e., artificial materials composed, instead of atoms, of tiny metallic resonators, their employment required solving such problems, as homogenization of the media, inter-resonator coupling, extremely narrow frequency band, and increased losses at higher frequencies that restricted realization of TO-based photonic devices. 

In this project, artificial materials of another type, dielectric Photonic Crystals (PhCs), were investigated as alternative media for TO-based devices. Since electromagnetic responses of PhCs are defined rather by their periodicity than by resonances in their “atoms”, transformation media composed of PhCs is free from major limitations of MM media. Although attention to PhCs has been primarily focused on crystals with complete bandgaps in their energy diagrams, we have demonstrated that by strategically modifying lattice cells of crystals formed from dielectric rod arrays, it is possible to create the media providing prescribed anisotropic spatial dispersion of material parameters to satisfy most sophisticated TO requests. We have shown that our designs of invisibility cloaks and wave collimators could be scaled for operation in the ranges from microwaves to optics by changing the size and dielectric permittivity of rods forming the arrays.

To obtain in  dielectric PhCs challenging material parameters, prescribed by TO for the media of cylindrical invisibility cloaks, i.e., superluminal indices of refraction in one direction and conventional indices exceeding 1 in orthogonal direction, we first found parameters at which PhCs’ dispersion diagrams provided positive refraction in the 2nd transmission band with indices below 1 and, thus, wave propagation with superluminal phase velocities. Then we designed crystals with rectangular lattices exhibiting different spatial index dispersions along two orthogonal crystallographic directions, one with indexes changing in “superluminal” range, and another one- with conventional indexes. In addition, we developed a new type of unidirectional invisibility cloak employing the phenomenon of self-collimation, specific for PhCs, i.e., the ability to launch waves along bent crystallographic paths, for turning wave paths around the target, while TO approaches were used to design input and output parts of the cloak. The new cloak was thinner, compared to the TO-based cloak and did not require challenging PhC parameters. The performance of both types of cloaks was confirmed by full-wave simulations and microwave experiments with prototypes formed from arrays of ceramic rods with mm-size diameters.

Another type of highly anisotropic dielectric PhCs was developed for providing collimation effect for divergent waves. We designed 2D crystals composed of dielectric rods and organized in rectangular lattices with precisely determined lattice constants, which supported unidirectional wave propagation with near-zero refractive indices (NZRIs) along one crystallographic direction. Wave propagation along orthogonal direction was fully suppressed because of provided transmission bandgap, that resulted in collimation of incident divergent waves. For experimental verification of full-wave simulation results, fabricated samples were composed of ceramic rods. Obtained results extend perspectives of low-loss artificial anisotropic media with NZRI properties. Developed collimators can have many potential applications in electromagnetics and photonics, such as enhancing the gain and directionality of antennas’ radiation and connecting waveguides with different widths.

Obtaining the most sophisticated material parameters of PhC media opens new perspectives for utilizing PhCs in various TO-based applications. An important factor for broader impacts of this work is mature technological and material base developed for PhCs fabrication compared to that existing for fabricating MMs. Many types of low-loss PhCs for operation in various frequency ranges including optics have been produced and studied experimentally. This will help implementing PhCs in practical TO-based devices at frequencies from microwave to optical range. The project has presented an excellent multidisciplinary training environment for the students, who participated in the project-related research, exposing them to the studies in the areas of electromagnetics, physics, and material science; to full-wave electromagnetic simulations, and to state-of-the-art microwave experiments. Four PhD students were supported by the project funds. The topics related to the work on the project have been incorporated in the graduate and undergraduate courses taught by the PI. The results of this interdisciplinary work were disseminated through journal publications and presentations at the major international forums in the field. A book, based on original research performed by the PI with PhD students was published by ELSEVIER, Woodhead Publishing Series in Electronic and Optical Materials.
